newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asian Metals - Trade divided on Chile strike impact.
newsitem.headline: Asian Metals - Trade divided on Chile strike impact.

text.p: Asian metal dealers were divided in their opinion on Wednesday over the market impact of a strike at the world's biggest copper mine in northern Chile.

Some dealers said the strike by about 300 of the 2,000 workers at the Escondida mine may prompt a spike in copper prices later on Wednesday on the London Metal Exchange (LME), while others believed there would be no impact at all.
"Psychologically, it makes an impact. Fundamentally, it shouldn't," Vinod Kumar, director of Singapore metal company Donald Mcarthy, told Reuters.
The workers at Escondida, owned by Broken Hill Proprietary Corp Plc and RTZ Corp Plc, voted to strike on Tuesday after rejecting a company pay offer.
A trader for a European metal house added: "The news will have a psychological impact. It may push copper back up again."
Dealers said three month copper on the LME, which closed on Tuesday at US$2,281 a tonne, may rise to $2,300 on the news.
Some traders said LME operators could use the Escondida news as an opportunity to buy and then unload copper if the contract approaches $2,300.
"It will be a good chance to pickup stuff and then people will sell it off just as quickly," a trader said.
Other base metal traders, however, believe the impact of the strike will be limited.
"It's only 15 percent of the work force. That number is quite easily replaceable," a dealer for another European trader said.
"What impact?" a dealer in Singapore asked. "There's no impact out here. The number of workers in the mine are too few."
"I called a few guys this morning and they all want to see more news on whether the strike will get worse," a trader said.
Three month copper was quoted by the trade at 0330 GMT at $2,276/81 a tonne, slightly easier than the London close.
"Despite (yesterday's) bounce off the recent lows, the market needs to close above $2,310 to reverse the negative chart picture in the short-term," broker Brandeis said in its daily review.

Copper premiums in Singapore were also unaffected by the Escondida news and were even quoted easier by the trade at between $20-$30 a tonne compared to yesterday's $20-$40 a tonne. "There's no strength in the market," Kumar said, adding that business around Southeast Asia was "mostly routine."
One dealer said demand for other base metals in the region was steady "but not spectacular. I think the mood in the market will continue to remain bearish."
Three month aluminium was seen by the trade at 0330 GMT at $1,553/57 a tonne against the close in London on Tuesday of $1,555 a tonne.
Singapore indications as a premium to LME cash prices (Warrant/premiums):

Aluminium - Western (20-25 kg ingots) +60-85 +60-85
Aluminium - Indian (20-25 kg ingots) +40-60 +40-55

-- Singapore Newsroom (65-8703305)
